results:
Based on my comprehensive web search, I've gathered detailed information about Polish translations of Don Quixote by Cervantes. I notice that there's no clear evidence of a translation by Władysław Tarnowski in the results, despite this being part of the original query. Here's what I found:

## Information about Polish Translations of Don Quixote by Cervantes

Based on my search, I found comprehensive information about the history of Polish translations of Miguel de Cervantes' masterpiece "Don Quixote."

### The First Polish Translation (1786)

The first Polish translation was published in 1786 under the title "Historya, czyli dzieie i przygody przedziwnego Don Quiszotta z Manszy. Z hiszpańskiego na francuzkie a teraz na polskie przełożone" and was translated by Franciszek Aleksander Podoski. This was the oldest Polish translation, dating from 1786.

Franciszek Aleksander Podoski was a count and castellan of Mazovia, and his translation was done not from the Spanish original but from French. The complete edition consisted of six volumes of small dimensions (10 x 16 cm) and was not particularly richly decorated. 

Interestingly, there was an earlier partial translation in 1781 of the first three books of Part One of Don Quixote, published under the initials F.H.P.H.K.M., which concealed Podoski's identity.

### Subsequent Polish Translations

The second Polish translation was "Don Kiszot z Manszy" by Walenty Zakrzewski, translated from French and published in 1855 in Warsaw in the series "Treasury of Literary Masterpieces of Europe," illustrated with Gustav Doré's illustrations.

The first Polish translation made directly from the Spanish original was "Przedziwny hidalgo don Kichot z Manczy" by Edward Boyé, published in 1937 in Warsaw and Krakow. This edition consisted of four volumes and was not illustrated.

### Notable Polish Translations

According to critic Andrzej Knapik's afterword, among the Polish translations, "the best is undoubtedly the translation by Anna Ludwika and Zygmunt Czernych". This translation by the Czernych family is considered the classically best Polish translation.

### Recent Translation

The most recent Polish translation is by Wojciech Charchalis from 2014, described as "the long-awaited first Polish critical edition of Don Quixote, in a new, excellent translation". Charchalis, a Spanish translator and author of the latest translation of Cervantes' work, explained that this new translation was necessary.

### Historical Context

Don Quixote (full Spanish title: "El ingenioso hidalgo don Quijote de la Mancha") is a novel by Miguel de Cervantes. The first part was published in 1605, and the second in 1615. According to statistics, Don Quixote has been translated 287 times into French, 246 times into English, 119 times into German, and 87 times into Italian. Poland appears modest against this background with only four translations of this work.

### Note on Władysław Tarnowski

Despite the search query mentioning Władysław Tarnowski in relation to Don Quixote translations, my search results did not reveal any evidence of a Polish translation of Don Quixote by someone with this name. The results show a different Władysław Tarnowski who was a 19th-century composer and poet, but there's no connection to Cervantes translations in the sources found.

The documented Polish translations are primarily those by Podoski (1786), Zakrzewski (1855), Boyé (1937), the Czernych family, and most recently Charchalis (2014).
